document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomy and phylogeny of Koinocystididae (Platyhelminthes, Kalyptorhynchia) with the description of three new genera and twelve new species

subSubSection.paragraph:
Known distribution. Bahia de Santos ( Type Locality) and Pitangueiras, S√£o Sebasti√£o, Brazil (see Marcus 1949 for details). Three localities in Galapagos Islands and several in Cura√ßao (see
Reygel et al. 2011
for details).

New records and material. Observations on live specimens. Three whole mounts from Siboney ( 19¬∞57‚Äô34‚ÄùN ; 75¬∞42‚Äô07‚ÄùW ), Santiago de Cuba , Cuba (February 7 & May 15, 2016 ; April 4, 2017 ) (HU XIII .2.42‚Äì XIII .2.44), intertidal up to 0.6 m deep, fine-grained sand, salinity 32‚Äì35 ‚Ä∞. One whole mount from La Mula ( 19¬∞56‚Äô44‚ÄùN ; 76¬∞45‚Äô19‚ÄùW ), Guam√°, Santiago de Cuba , Cuba ( June 29, 2016 ) (HU XIII .2.45), intertidal rocky pools, on the algae
Digenia simplex
and
Cladophoropsis macromeres
, salinity 33 ‚Ä∞. One whole mount from Macab√≠ ( 20¬∞54‚Äô13‚ÄùN ; 75¬∞43‚Äô40‚ÄùW ), Banes, Holgu√≠n , Cuba ( April 23, 2017 ) (HU XIII .2.46), fine-grained sand, 0.3 m deep, salinity 34 ‚Ä∞. Three whole mounts from a beach east of the Marine Research Station of Achotines ( 07¬∞24‚Äô47‚ÄùN ; 80¬∞10‚Äô20‚ÄùW ), Vera Cruz, Panama ( February 28, 2016 ) ( USNM 1642500‚Äì1642502), just over the rocky hill, on green algae (
Blidingia
/
Enteromorpha
-like). One whole mount (HU XIII .2.47) and one serially-sectioned specimen (HU XIII .2.48) collected in Anse Vata Bay ( 22¬∞18‚Äô19‚ÄùS ; 166¬∞26‚Äô50‚ÄùE ), Noum√©a, New Caledonia ( October 22, 2003 ), on algae (
Ulva
-like) and sediment taken from rocks in the mouth of a small river.

Remarks. Habitus and overall anatomical organisation of our specimens correspond to the description by Marcus (1949) . The specimens are unpigmented, with two eyes. The specimens from Cuba are 0.8‚Äì1 mm long ( xÃÑ = 0.9 mm ; n = 5), the specimens from Panama are 0.9‚Äì1.3 mm long ( xÃÑ = 1.1 mm ; n = 2), and the specimen from New Caledonia is 1 mm long. The syncytial epidermis is 3 Œºm thick (in the serially-sectioned specimen from New Caledonia ) and completely ciliated. Cilia 2‚Äì3 Œºm long. The epidermis has a thin basal lamina and is lined internally by a thick layer of circular muscles. Rhabdites present over the entire body surface, more numerous in the posterior body half, 2‚Äì3 Œºm long.

The proboscis has the characteristic koinocystidid construction, with a strong juncture sphincter (see Brunet 1972 ; Karling 1980 ). It is 10% of the body length in live specimens from Panama and 15% in the specimens from Cuba and New Caledonia .

The pharynx ( Fig. 1A ) is located in the anterior body half. Its diameter is 15% of the body length in live specimens from Panama and New Caledonia and 20% in specimens from Cuba . The prepharyngeal cavity ( Fig. 1A : ppc) is lined by a low, nucleated epithelium (thicker in the distal 1/3 of the lumen) and surrounded by an external layer of longitudinal muscles. Four types of glands open very close to each other in the distal part of the pharynx lumen: two types containing a coarse-grained eosinophilic secretion, one stained yellowish ( Fig. 1A : phg4) and the other stained brownish ( Fig. 1A : phg1), one containing a fine-grained eosinophilic secretion (stained pinkish) ( Fig. 1A : phg2), and one a coarse-grained basophilic secretion (stained dark blue-black) ( Fig. 1A : phg3). Coarse-grained basophilic glands (Minot‚Äôs glands; Fig. 1A : oeg) open into the oesophagus ( Fig. 1A : oe). The musculature of the pharynx consists of a layer of longitudinal muscles outside of the septum ( Fig. 1A : lm), which is continuous with that surrounding the prepharyngeal cavity, and a circular one just inside of the septum ( Fig. 1A : cm1). The distal opening of the pharynx is lined by a thick layer of longitudinal muscles, which in sagittal sections gives the impression of forming a lip-like structure ( Fig. 1A : slm). The pharynx lumen is surrounded by a low epithelium and an outer layer of circular muscles ( Fig. 1A : cm2) and an inner layer of longitudinal muscles ( Fig. 1A : ilm). Radial muscles ( Fig. 1A : rm) run between the internal and the external walls. The mouth ( Fig. 1A : m) is surrounded by a sphincter ( Fig. 1A : sph).

The oviform copulatory bulb ( Fig. 1B‚ÄìC ) is 76‚Äì86 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 81 Œºm; n = 5) in the specimens from Cuba , 86‚Äì89 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 88 Œºm; n = 2) in the specimens from Panama , and 130 Œºm long in the specimen from New Caledonia . The spiny cirrus as a whole ( Fig. 1B‚ÄìC : ci) is 35‚Äì41Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 38 Œºm; n = 5) and 29‚Äì37 Œºm wide ( xÃÑ = 33 Œºm; n = 2) in the specimens from Cuba , 20‚Äì36 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 29 Œºm; n = 3), and 28‚Äì44 Œºm wide ( xÃÑ = 36 Œºm; n = 2) in the specimens from Panama , and 57 Œºm long and 36 Œºm wide in the specimen from New Caledonia . The cirrus is formed by transverse, sclerotised folds bearing tightly-packed spines. Spines are 2‚Äì3 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 2 Œºm; n = 25) in the specimens from Cuba and New Caledonia , and 3‚Äì4 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 4 Œºm; n = 25) in the specimens from Panama .
